data.title: Vocabulary
data.text:
Turkish-English Vocabulary

You can adjust the font size of the text on this page by using your browser's preferences. You can search for a word by using your browser's find utility. You can also jump to a section by clicking on a letter in the alphabet below.

A B C Ã D E F G Ä H I Ä° J K L M N O Ã P R S Å T U Ã V Y Z

This vocabulary of approximately 2,000 words includes all the essential words in Almanyadan Gelecek Mektup, all common in Turkish spoken today.Â

Alphabetical Order of Headwords and Subentries

Headwords and subentries appear in alphabetical order word-by-word rather than letter-by-letter. Thus akÅam vakti precedes akÅama; kapÄ± vurulâ precedes kapÄ±dan Ã§Ä±kâ; sÃ¶z verâ precedes sÃ¶zden dÃ¶nâ.

The Form of Headwords

Headwords appear in the form they have in the novel. Where multiple forms occur, they are shown separated by a slash (meaning âorâ), with the most frequently occurring form first. This is often a matter of word division: her gÃ¼n / hergÃ¼n.

The form of headwords in this novel may differ from their form elsewhere. For example, this novel has zerafet, but the more common form, as noted in the Redhouse Turkish-English Dictionary (2000), is zarafet. In some cases word division is different, e.g. Ã¶te beri in the novel, Ã¶teberi in Redhouse.Â

Verbs are entered by their stems, with the final -mak / -mek replaced by a dash in bold (â). In the corresponding English verbs, a dash (â) stands for âto.â Thus aramak appears as follows: araâ 1. â look for, seek, look up. 2. â ask for, call (on telephone). The dash distinguishes the verb from the noun ara.Â

Placement of Entries and Subentries

Expressions written as two or more words, such as phrases, compounds, idioms, sayings and proverbs, appear as subentries under the word with which they begin. Thus adet yerini bulsun appears under adet; anlam verâ appears under anlam; apartman dairesi appears under apartman.Â

Also appearing as subentries are single words beginning with the same word or element as the headword and semantically related to it, alphabetical order permitting. Thus adamcaÄÄ±z (1. poor man. 2. dear man) is a subentry under adam (man).

If alphabetical order does not permit, related words appear below as a main entry. Thus the word Ã¶lÃ¼ (dead person) derived from Ã¶lâ (to die), is not a subentry under Ã¶lâ but a main entry because the word Ã¶lÃ§Ã¼ (measure) comes alphabetically between the two items. In accord with this principle of subordination, passive and causative verbs often appear under the active form. Thus asÄ±lâ (â hang, to be hung) appears as a subentry under asâ /A/ (â hang sth /to/on/). This system calls the readerâs attention to related words and word composition.Â

The Aorist Form of VerbsÂ

Verbs with unpredictable aorist tense forms are followed by an abbreviation of the form, e.g. alâ, âÄ±r. Here âÄ±r stands for the aorist tense alÄ±r. In this we follow the practice ofRedhouse (2000). For the rules governing the formation of the aorist tense, see GÃ¶ksel and Kerslake (2005) or Lewis (2000).

Pronunciation of Headwords

Noun headwords not stressed on the final syllable or including long vowels are followed in parentheses by an indication of syllable stress and length. A dot (.) stands for a short syllable, a hyphen (-) for a long one. An accented syllable has an accent mark (â) after and slightly above it, e.g. acaba (.â..), acaip (.-.), Aferin (-â..). These markings reflect the sounds of current spoken Turkish.Â

Within a noun, the apostrophe indicates a glottal stop: neÅâe (this is the only instance in this novel).

Noun Headwords with Irregularly Inflected Final Letters or SyllablesÂ

Such nouns are followed by an abbreviation of their accusative case forms: adet, -ti. Here -ti stands for adeti. Similarly: aÄÄ±z, -ÄzÄ± (for aÄzÄ±); kalp, -bi (for kalbi). This information is included because, even if these forms do not occur in this novel, they may be needed for exercises based on its vocabulary. Â

Cases Headwords Require

Case suffixes that a headword requires appear between slashes. Upper-case letters represent sounds that vary according to the rules of vowel or consonant harmony. Lower-case letters represent those that do not vary.Â

/A/ indicates the dative case, usually translated as âto.â The standard linguistic abbreviation â(y)A represents â(y)a/â(y)e.Â

/DA/ indicates the locative case, usually translated as âat,â âin,â or âon.â The standard linguistic abbreviation âDA represents âda/âde/âta/âte.Â

/DAn/ indicates the ablative case, usually translated as âfrom.â The standard linguistic abbreviation âDAn represents âdan/âden/âtan/âten.Â

/I/ indicates the accusative case, often translated as âthe.â The standard linguistic abbreviation â(y)I represents â(y)Ä±/â(y)i/â(y)u/â(y)Ã¼.Â

The corresponding English equivalents, mostly prepositions, also appear between slashes. If the equivalent translation is one that is less commonly anticipated, that is, when, for example, /A/ is not translated as âto,â that equivalent appears in capital letters. If there is no separate equivalent, /Ã/ usually appears. Thus: ait (-.) /A/ 1. relating /to/, concerning /Ã/. 2. belonging /to/; and alÄ±Å veriÅ etâ /DAn/ â do business /with/.Â

Where one case suffix may have more than one English equivalent, the equivalents appear separated by slashes signifying âorâ: atâ /A/ 1. â throw /AT/ON/IN/.Â

Where either one of two case suffixes may be appropriate for any one of the English equivalents shown, both case suffixes appear separated by a slash, meaning âorâ: alÄ±nâ /A/DAn/ â take offense /AT/, â be offended /BY/.Â

Where multiple suffixes in a certain sequence have equivalents in the same sequence, the suffixes in Turkish and the English equivalents are separated by a comma: Ã§ekâ 1. /DAn, A/ â pull /from, to/.

The accusative suffix is shown in a headword unit only where readers might have difficulty with its use. Thus it appears in the following, where experience has shown that readers tend to expect the dative case, /A/, rather than the accusative: bekleâ /I/ 1. â wait /for/. 2. â expect.

Postpositions and Other Elements Associated with Headwords

Slashes also enclose postpositions and phrases that commonly occur with the headword.Â

/lA/ represents the postposition ile, attached form -(y)lA, usually translated as âwith.â The standard linguistic abbreviation -(y)lA/ile represents -(y)la/-(y)le/ile; for example: alay etâ /lA/ â joke, kid, make fun /OF/.Â

An example with a case suffix and an additional element is ilerleâ /DAn, A doÄru/ â move forward /from, toward/, /A doÄru/ head /for/, /A doÄru/ make oneâs way /toward/, advance.

Treatment of Place Names

Turkish place names appear in the translation because they can easily be accessed in this form on the Internet. This vocabulary provides only enough information about each place to indicate its relevance to this novel.Â

Definitions

Definitions are limited to those relevant to this novel. Where there are alternative definitions, they are usually in order from most common to least common as they are found in the language in general.Â

Cross-references to Other Entries

An arrow at the end of an entry (â) directs the reader to other entries that include the original headword in other than initial position. These items are arranged alphabetically.
